title: Thursday, 16th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

So, yeah, sorry. Slighty late today.

BE11:06am

(This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's typing thing, by the way.)

BE11:06am

Because Slack's down.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

And we can't work under these conditions.

BE11:06am

It's difficult to continue a normal AV service without having its perpetual private backchannel of snarky office gossip and mildly amusing gifs.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Nevertheless, contractual obligation demands we plough on.

BE11:07am

Even though Slack's lack also means I've not had time to sort out cover for Paul. So you've got me solo today. Sorry about that.

undefined
11:07 am
BE11:08am

And we'd best start at the top of the fallers.

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 290.70, down 20.1 (-6.47%), High: 296.30, Low: 280.00, Volume: 15.20m
BE11:08am

Profit warning part two.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

CEO designate Kevin Cummings is off with immediate effect.

BE11:09am

He was due to remove "designate" from his Linkedin page on January 1st.

BE11:10am

Which currently says he's CEO of GKN Aerospace, and before that CEO and President of Aerostructures - North America.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

We also get another writedown, £80-130m, equivalent to 1.5%-2.4% of market cap.

BE11:11am

So. That's switching CEO twice in the space of one year.

BE11:12am

Suggesting something's seriously up at aerospace.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Plus you have a current non-exec getting dropped in.

BE11:13am

Which is the kind of thing companies do as part of a strategic review leading to a breakup ..........

BE11:13am

.......... a theme we've touched upon here repeatedly, of course.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@The Specialist: sorry, you're getting blocked by our hyperactive content filter. I'll try and repair on the sly.)

BE11:14am

That's the upshot of Numis's argument. This is David Larkham, who bites the bullet and turns positive.

BE11:14am

The bad news is that the issues in US aerospace are significantly worse than previously announced. The good news is that the door is now open for a new external CEO to come in and carry out a thorough, impartial review to maximise the inherent value in the group. This will take time and may be painful (more cost/write downs possible) but this also increases the possibility that the inherent value in the group can be released. A stock for the brave as it was in 2008 when it had two warnings within a similar time-scale, the difference this time is that the issues are self inflicted and the balance sheet does not require refinancing.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

One unknown is whether GKN Aerospace has been left with a load of useless spare parts because of overbuild or wrongly valued inventory.

BE11:16am

It's the difference between operational failure and accounting slackness, I guess.

BE11:18am

Either way, Cummings has gone.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

That much we can say for certain anything else is speculation. Here's RBC.

BE11:19am

The review was triggered by the problems at the Alabama plant highlighted in the Q3 profit warning and is not yet complete. While there is clearly some risk that the final number is higher, the wideness of the range and its size (~40% of Aerospace profits at the top end) suggest that there may have been some element of ‘kitchen sinking’ with the announcement. In terms of what is being written-off, the statement flags that much of it was built up before 2017, suggesting to us that it is largely an inventory problem relating to military programmes that have either now ended or are in decline. All other guidance for the full year remains unchanged.

Another knock to confidence. This update comes just over a month after the Q3 profit warning, which took ~10% of consensus 2017 profits. That was triggered by two customer claims (one each at Aerospace and Driveline), as well a weaker than anticipated top-line and margin performance at Aerospace. It also flagged a £15m charge non-cash charge relating to revised assumptions on programme inventory and receivables at its Alabama,
USA facility, which is what prompted the further review.
While today’s warning is clearly more one-off in nature than October’s, it is a major knock to management credibility. The turmoil may be seen by some as perhaps making a break up more likely and we expect that investors will continue to see value creation potential in such a scenario. The appointment of an independent interim CEO may also prompt some fresh thinking. However today’s update will also further call into question the attractions of GKN Aerospace as a stand-alone business, given it appears that margins have been overstated in the past.

BE11:20am

Note, by the way, that this all comes very shortly after GKN hosted a tour of its driveline plant in Birmingham.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Slightly awkwardly, Jefferies and Merrill both stuck out buy notes on that first thing this morning, before the aerospace stuff blew up.

BE11:21am

(@Lemmy: a £1.5bn pension hole is the hurdle to clear for that argument.)

BE11:22am

Quick update from Jefferies ......

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Reading between the lines, issues have been stored up in Aerospace North America in the shape of working capital that is over-valued. This could be inventories, although it is hard to imagine such a large amount of slow-moving material could have escaped notice. It could be debtors where there was £122m overdue at end FY16. The related cash is gone, in our view. Our forecasts did not assume a reduction in working capital and so may not be heavily impacted.

BE11:23am

All of which seems to add up to a company not entirely under control.

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 291.70, down 19.1 (-6.15%), High: 296.30, Low: 280.00, Volume: 15.79m
11:23 am
undefined
BE11:23am

Okay, what else?

BE11:24am

Lots of ex divs. RDS, Bunzl, Imps, MKS, Sainsbury, Sophos, Spire (albeit only 1.3p, or about 0.4%).

11:24 am
BE11:24am

There's also Dignity.

Dignity PLC (DTY:LSE): Last: 2,000, down 165 (-7.62%), High: 2,112, Low: 1,943, Volume: 383.21k
BE11:25am

Down, what, 20% now since the last set of numbers.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Which looked okay on the surface, but spooked everyone with talk of competition.

BE11:25am

Now, what I hadn't fully appreciated about Dignity pre those numbers is how reliant it has been on price gouging.

BE11:26am

Though it's obvious in retrospect. The death rate has been pretty stable for the decade or so it's been listed, and its market share for funerals has flatlined.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

BE11:26am

Yet EBIT's gone from £46m to £80m in that period. EPS CAGR of 16%.

BE11:26am

Okay, so that's partly because it's bought a lot of crematoria (EBIT of £15m to £42m in a decade) but mostly on price inflation for funerals.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

The upshot here is that Dignity and the Co-op have been using their market dominance to hike prices.

BE11:27am

(Colluding? That's not for me to say. That'd be up to the competition regulator, if we had one.)

BE11:27am

Now, though, Dignity and the Co-Op have hiked prices so much, there's a bunch of startup funeral directors saying "we'll have some of that."

11:28 am
BE11:28am

(@Vixal: comment content filter is very edgy this morning. Not sure why. We'll try to fix, apologies.)

BE11:28am

.... Which is what Berenberg points out this morning.

BE11:28am

[Dignity] is seeing increased competition from new entrants and people searching for providers online, affecting pricing in funeral services. Given that our investment case is predicated on Dignity’s ability to deliver long-term growth in part thanks to strong pricing power, until its competitive response to these challenges is clarified, we are more cautious on it. As a result, we downgrade to Hold and reduce our price target to 2,350p to reflect the likely impact of lower pricing power and subsequently lower growth in the mature business.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Over the past 12 months, management has become incrementally more bearish about the competitive environment. Historically, Dignity has prioritised price over volume to drive strong margin expansion. However, increasing competition means that the company’s ability to continue raising prices at 5-6% pa looks uncertain. With management now examining various new pricing and service options, we see a risk that it is forced to moderate its pricing to chase lower-margin business. As a result, we reduce our long-run margin assumptions.

BE11:29am

So, remove price gouging from the model and 16 times 2018 begins to look pretty expensive.

BE11:29am

While we remain comfortable that Dignity can deliver on consensus expectations for FY 2017 and FY 2018, the likelihood of it delivering upgrades is low, in our view, given the competitive headwinds and investment in the company’s digital offering. Consequently, we feel the current multiple fairly reflects Dignity’s lower growth profile and limited scope for earnings upgrades.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

(Also .... 16 times 2018! For a market that only grows when there's a very cold winter or a natural disaster. That in itself tells you that something's up here.)

undefined
BE11:31am

Godalmighty, what's this?

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Dear Colleague,
For the first time ever, a Bitcoin ATM has been installed in a bank branch. The branch is located in Mosonmagyaróvár, on the Hungarian side of the Hungarian-Slovak-Austrian tri-border area.

BE11:31am

.......... right.

BE11:32am

Operated by Shinrai Kft., the ATM, contributing to the brand expansion of Bitcoin trading network MrCoin, will be serving clients in the new sub-office of VirPay, opened on Friday, an online service offering bank-independent account management and other virtual financial services. This makes it the world’s first Bitcoin ATM to be commissioned in a service provider’s branch office.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

This is the same outfit that put a Bitcoin ATM in a Budapest pub a few years ago. A disruptive innovation in the area of allowing drunk people the opportunity to impulse-buy something they can't use and don't understand.

BE11:32am

[T]he new ATM is capable of far more than its Budapest counterpart: this model, manufactured by GeneralBytes, can accept and dispense Euro and Forint banknotes alike. And, in addition to purchasing and selling Bitcoins, it will also be enabled to exchange Ethereum, Bitcoin Cash, and Litecoin. The ATM naturally supports transactions involving fractional units smaller than the exchange rate for one unit. The only constraint to pay attention to is the minimum purchase limit of HUF 5,000. The company, based in London but also offering its services to Hungarians, serves clients with both online and telephone customer service, should any questions arise regarding the use of the ATM.

BE11:33am

And wait! There's a picture.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

BE11:33am

And wait! There's a quote.

BE11:33am

“For years now, people have been told that Bitcoin is a passing fad, a bubble. However, the developments based on the Blockchain technology, which ensures the security of Bitcoins, are increasingly reshaping the environment of mainstream financial institutions as well,” said Barnabás Debreczeni, Managing Director of Shinrai Kft., commenting on the opening.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

I'd be more confident that Bitcoin is a passing fad if it showed any sign whatsoever of passing. The daily email bumpf suggests otherwise.

BE11:34am

(@Pseudonym: meh.)

undefined
11:35 am
BE11:35am

What else can I repurpose from my emails to keep us ticking?

BE11:35am

Oh, here's one. Deutsche Tel bidding for BT.

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 243.50, down 3.65 (-1.48%), High: 248.15, Low: 242.70, Volume: 6.27m
11:36 am
BE11:36am

As in, the hypothetical possibility of DT bidding for BT!

BE11:36am

I hope that didn't confuse the bots.

BE11:05am

Weren't even sure we could go on.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

And as a reminder, BT's purchase of EE has locked DT into holding no more than 15 per cent of BT for three years, as in until 2019.

BE11:38am

You'll remember also that earlier this year, DT moved its 12 per cent of BT into an active investment-management unit managed by Thorsten Langheim, their M&A bod.

BE11:38am

Everyone read that as a signal that DT is more likely to exit the stake than retain it as a platform for a bid.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

But when share prices halve, plans can change. Maybe.

BE11:38am

Or maybe not.

BE11:38am

Over to Saeed Baradar, Louis Capital.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

THAT WILL NEVER HAPPEN!

BE11:38am

Thumbs up

BE11:39am

ANY THOUGHTS OF A DT BID FOR BT ARE NOTHING MORE THAN FANTASY!

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Thumbs up

BE11:39am

What's your thinking here, Mr Baradar?

BE11:39am

DT AND BT HAVE DIFFERENT CONTENT STRATEGIES - ONE IS RIGHT - THE OTHER IS WRONG

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Thumbs up

BE11:39am

DT's management content strategy is in total contrast to BT - DT is a content aggregator, rather than the value destroying BT strategy, of over inflated sports content acquisition. Furthermore, BT is still under regulatory pressure on its wholesale access, its pension fund deficit payments are set to increase following the ongoing triennial valuation and its unsustainable dividend policy is set to further pressurise an FCF which has been recently downgraded.

BE11:39am

Anything else?

11:39 am
BE11:39am

INTERNATIONAL ASSETS - ONE HAS THE THE BEST AND THE OTHER THE WORST

BE11:40am

Thumbs up

BE11:40am

TMOB US represents the best international asset of any European operator undergoing the strongest growth in the sector where I forecast FCF to grow from $1.4bn in 2016 to over $4.5bn in 2019. BT's Global services division in my view is the worst asset of any European operator and more recently has been impacted by a clear lack of internal controls as evidenced by the accounting scandal in Italy and anti-competitive behaviour in Hong-Kong. DT's conservative management team will never want those assets or the headache to dispose of them (which is practically impossible in one go implying a slow break up and significant value leak) when in reality there is probably no realistic buyer out there!

11:40 am
BE11:40am

He's a .... wait .... let me check ...... he's a ......

BE11:40am

.... seller of BT.

BE11:40am

Just in case that wasn't clear.

11:40 am
undefined
BE11:42am

Turning to requests ...................

Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,878, up 17.5 (+0.94%), High: 1,890, Low: 1,837, Volume: 2.94m
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Q3 IMS is pretty solid, though not unexpectedly.

BE11:43am

Life new business profit up 17% y/y

BE11:43am

Or 26% without FX

11:43 am
BE11:43am

That compares to 20% in the first half

BE11:44am

Asia 15%, US 17%, UK ...... 31%!

BE11:44am

US is the mild disappointment here. Bit slower due to regulatory flux.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

And there's an investor day ongoing, from which I've heard nothing yet.

BE11:45am

Merger of M&G with Prudential UK the obvious focus. Let me cut to some sellside.

BE11:46am

Jefferies ..........

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Total VNB + 17%: New business momentum still strong across all regions though tailing off slightly VNB +17% Q3 (vs 1H +20%), with Asia, UK and UK +15%, 17%, 31% (Q3) vs +18%, 23%, 29% (1H).
Growth trends continue across group: Asia has delivered double digit growth in 8 countries both VNB and APE. The single digit rise in APE overall reflects withdrawal from HK brokerage, where ex HK APE +24%. US VA flows remain strong, though with management still citing DOL uncertainties hampering the shorter term outlook. The UK remains supported by the popularity of the PruFund offering. Positive flow trends continue at M&G, annualised 8% Q3 (vs 10% 1H), although slowed somewhat at Eastspring at just 1% for Q3. SII ratio 201% down slightly vs 1H at 202% dragged by currency, but still supported by continued strong capital generation, at £2.3bn 9m, giving an annual run-rate in growth pre dividend of 23pts.

BE11:47am

And Panmure.

BE11:47am

The growth and new business profit in Q3 reinforce our SOTP valuation model that generates our 2210p target price. We believe that today will be about emphasising the huge opportunities that exist in each of these areas. In Asia the health, protection and savings of the rapidly growing middle class, in the US the retirement income needs of the baby-boomers and in the UK the opportunity created by the converging life and savings markets. Buy.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

We think that the investor day will be well received with emphasis
on the growth outlook in each of its operations. We note with interest the comment that “the presentations will demonstrate the strength of our positioning.....and the ability to respond with pace to new opportunities”. The shares are up 22% in the last 12 months and 14% YTD but in our view they remain very attractively priced trading at a 16% discount to our sum of the parts (SOTP) valuation at 2210p/share.

undefined
BE11:49am

While on the financials, should probably mention the Virgin Money warning.

11:49 am
Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 261.10, down 13.9 (-5.05%), High: 267.00, Low: 257.80, Volume: 3.79m
BE11:50am

Which is a chance to revisit one of our standard themes, "what exactly are challenger banks for?"

BE11:51am

So, for 2018 Virgin's guiding us to a gross mortgage lending share at lower end of its 3.0-3.5% targeted range

11:51 am
BE11:51am

And credit card balances growing in mid-single digits (versus c30%
for 2017).

BE11:52am

And banking net interest margin comes back to 165-170 bips, from 173 bips in the first half.

BE11:53am

All of this is rather lower than where the market was sitting.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Though it's been polished with some stuff about targeting SME and digital current accounts and etc.

BE11:54am

Here comes Barclays to summarise.

BE11:54am

Key guidance is for RoTE to remain ‘solid double-digit’, share of gross mortgage lending at the lower end of the 3-3.5% target range with credit card growth slowing to mid single-digit and for the banking net interest margin to be 1.65% to 1.70% from just above 1.70% in 2017. Bloomberg consensus of a 12% RoTE and 12% loan growth looks consistent although the margin pressure could be something of a negative. Capital is expected to be at the upper end of a 12-13% range, consistent with consensus of 12.8%,

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Digital Bank won’t break even before 2021 – Beta phase testing in 2H18 with launch in 2019. Expected to add 3% to RoTE in the long term but will add 10% to costs in 2019 and take at least 3 years to break even. The proposition is centered on personal current accounts and is planned to acquire £5bn of deposits within 5 years and to reduce operating costs per customer by 40%.

BE11:54am

SME Banking – To be launched in January 2018, aims to raise £5bn deposits in 5 years and considering applying for funding from the RBS alternative state aid package to develop the business.

BE11:55am

Okay, so maybe I'm missing something fundamental here, but what does Virgin Money bring to SME banking that is either better or even slightly different from the incumbents?

11:56 am
BE11:56am

I don't doubt it'll hit its target of £5bn in SME deposits over 2018-23, I just don't quite understand why.

BE11:57am

Same question mortgages, which as noted right have been driven by buy-to-let.

BE11:58am

And we've talked in the past about Virgin Money's credit card book.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Four-fifths of which seems to be balance transfers.

BE11:59am

Where you can argue that it's pretty competitive ... https://uk.virginm...ce-transfer-cards/

BE11:59am

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

.... but you struggle a bit more to argue that its NPV of those balance transfers is realistic.

BE12:00pm

That was a key worry for Virgin investors because the bank offers a zero per cent teaser rate on balance transfers then assumes a 7 per cent effective rate for the life of the loan, whereas peers such as Barclays only assume 5 per cent.

BE12:00pm

That's me, quoting myself: https://www.ft.com...-91a7-502f7ee26895

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Anyway, have Ian Gordon at Investec. He's very positive.

BE12:01pm

The Virgin Money story so far has been on e of phenomenal loan growth driving rapidly improving operational leverage and, with ultra-low impairments, already very strong returns. Today’s investor day will outline a 5/6-year vision which Virgin expects to “lead to a material ROTE improvement over the longer-term”. The starting point is 12.9% ROTE in 2017e and a “solid double-digit ROTE” is targeted in 2018. Strong delivery now, with even more to come? BUY.

undefined
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Hey, look at the time. Haven't even mentioned Spire / Mediclinic.

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 275.20, down 21.4 (-7.22%), High: 293.20, Low: 271.60, Volume: 2.13m
BE12:03pm

Updates here, https://www.invest...1711160700036299W/ ("no agreement has yet been reached on any of the key terms of an offer" and http://ir.mediclin...797&p=irol-results
https://edge.media....com/m6/p/cqoz6cv5 (saying nothing whatsoever).

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Does this get done? No idea. Seems to me that since Mediclinic's offer was opportunistic it doesn't have much pressure on it to raise, could probably benefit from having management time not consumed by integration for the next year, and has limited downside as it holds a poison pill to any other bidder appearing.

BE12:08pm

Also, there's still a lot of confusion around new triage requirements for NHS patients to go private -- nearly a third of Spire revenues.

BE12:09pm

Add to that longstanding pressure on private insurance and you're left with self-funding, which is only a fifth of Spire revenues. Pretty damn difficult to find a value for this thing right now.

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

In that context, slightly surprised Spire is playing so hard to get. Still, whatever.

undefined
BE12:10pm

Okay, we're over time, apologies if I've missed your request.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Come back tomorrow when I'll probably miss it again.

BE12:12pm

Until then, thanks for the comments. If you want something DPL related to read over lunch I highly recommend this magazine piece on Blackpool from Sarah O'Connor: https://www.ft.com...-aa33-c63fdc9b8c6c

BE12:12pm

Has echoes of the kind of thing happening in Detroit a decade or so ago.

12:13 pm
BE12:13pm

Except with Jethro Tull as a soundtrack rather than Juan Atkins and Derek May.

BE12:13pm

Anyway, I'll leave you in peace now. Thanks all, and good afternoon.

BE11:37am

So anyway. When a price goes from above 500p to sub 250p, people start dragging out all the old theories.
